name: The Chapter on Householders

blurb: The Buddha discusses mindfulness meditation with lay practitioners. Contrasting the openness of animals with the duplicity of humans, he explains how to practice in a way that causes no harm to oneself or others.

main_text.mn51:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
main_text.mn51:1.3: Then Pessa the elephant driver’s son and Kandaraka the wanderer went to see the Buddha. When they had approached, Pessa bowed and sat down to one side.
main_text.mn51:1.4: But the wanderer Kandaraka exchanged greetings with the Buddha and stood to one side.
main_text.mn51:1.5: He looked around the mendicant Saṅgha, who were so very silent, and said to the Buddha:
main_text.mn51:10.1: And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
main_text.mn51:10.2: It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
main_text.mn51:10.3: He has a new temple built to the east of the city. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the temple with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
main_text.mn51:10.4: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
main_text.mn51:10.5: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the remainder.
main_text.mn51:10.7: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
main_text.mn51:10.8: His bondservants, employees, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
main_text.mn51:10.9: This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
main_text.mn51:11.1: And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, but lives without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves?
main_text.mn51:12.1: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
main_text.mn51:12.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
main_text.mn51:12.3: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
main_text.mn51:13.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan.
main_text.mn51:13.2: They gain faith in the Realized One,
main_text.mn51:13.4: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
main_text.mn51:13.5: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
main_text.mn51:13.6: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
main_text.mn51:13.7: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
main_text.mn51:14.1: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.
main_text.mn51:14.10: They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.
main_text.mn51:14.11: They avoid beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, perfumes, and makeup.
main_text.mn51:14.12: They avoid high and luxurious beds.
main_text.mn51:14.13: They avoid receiving gold and money,
main_text.mn51:14.2: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
main_text.mn51:14.22: They avoid running errands and messages;
main_text.mn51:14.26: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
main_text.mn51:14.3: They give up unchastity. They are celibate, set apart, avoiding the common practice of sex.
main_text.mn51:14.4: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.
main_text.mn51:14.5: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
main_text.mn51:14.6: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
main_text.mn51:14.7: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
main_text.mn51:14.8: They avoid injuring plants and seeds.
main_text.mn51:14.9: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
main_text.mn51:15.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
main_text.mn51:15.2: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
main_text.mn51:15.3: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
main_text.mn51:15.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
main_text.mn51:16.1: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
main_text.mn51:16.2: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
main_text.mn51:16.3: When they hear a sound with their ears …
main_text.mn51:16.4: When they smell an odor with their nose …
main_text.mn51:16.5: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
main_text.mn51:16.6: When they feel a touch with their body …
main_text.mn51:16.7: When they know a thought with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
main_text.mn51:16.8: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of desire and aversion would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
main_text.mn51:16.9: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
main_text.mn51:17.1: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
main_text.mn51:18.1: When they have this noble spectrum of ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
main_text.mn51:18.2: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
main_text.mn51:19.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.
main_text.mn51:19.2: Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
main_text.mn51:19.3: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.
main_text.mn51:19.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
main_text.mn51:19.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
main_text.mn51:19.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
main_text.mn51:2.2: How the mendicant Saṅgha has been led to practice properly by Master Gotama!
main_text.mn51:2.3: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly will at best do so
main_text.mn51:2.4: like Master Gotama does in the present.”
main_text.mn51:20.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
main_text.mn51:20.2: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
main_text.mn51:21.1: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and confidence, and unified mind, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
main_text.mn51:22.1: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
main_text.mn51:23.1: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
main_text.mn51:24.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
main_text.mn51:24.2: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
main_text.mn51:25.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
main_text.mn51:25.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
main_text.mn51:26.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
main_text.mn51:26.2: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
main_text.mn51:27.1: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
main_text.mn51:27.2: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
main_text.mn51:27.3: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
main_text.mn51:27.4: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
main_text.mn51:28.1: This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
main_text.mn51:28.2: They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.”
main_text.mn51:28.3: That is what the Buddha said.
main_text.mn51:28.4: Satisfied, the mendicants were happy with what the Buddha said.
main_text.mn51:3.1: “That’s so true, Kandaraka! That’s so true!
main_text.mn51:3.10: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
main_text.mn51:3.11: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
main_text.mn51:3.12: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
main_text.mn51:3.13: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.”
main_text.mn51:3.2: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly will at best do so
main_text.mn51:3.3: like I do in the present.
main_text.mn51:3.6: For in this mendicant Saṅgha there are perfected mendicants, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and are rightly freed through enlightenment.
main_text.mn51:3.7: And in this mendicant Saṅgha there are trainee mendicants who are consistently ethical, living consistently, alert, living alertly.
main_text.mn51:3.8: They meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
main_text.mn51:4.1: When he had spoken, Pessa said to the Buddha:
main_text.mn51:4.10: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though people continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.
main_text.mn51:4.11: For human beings are shady, sir,
main_text.mn51:4.13: For I can drive an elephant in training,
main_text.mn51:4.14: and while going back and forth in Campā it’ll try all the tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints that it can.
main_text.mn51:4.15: But my bondservants, employees, and workers behave one way by body, another by speech, and their minds another.
main_text.mn51:4.17: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though people continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.

main_text.mn51:4.3: how much the Buddha has clearly described the four kinds of mindfulness meditation! They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to end the cycle of suffering, and to realize extinguishment.
main_text.mn51:4.4: For we white-clothed laypeople also from time to time meditate with our minds well established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.

main_text.mn51:5.10: They live without wishes in the present life, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves.
main_text.mn51:5.11: Which one of these four people do you like the sound of?”
main_text.mn51:5.12: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three people.
main_text.mn51:5.16: I only like the sound of the last person, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”
main_text.mn51:5.4: Pessa, these four people are found in the world.
main_text.mn51:5.6: One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
main_text.mn51:5.7: One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
main_text.mn51:5.8: One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
main_text.mn51:5.9: One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
main_text.mn51:6.1: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three people?”
main_text.mn51:6.10: That’s why I like the sound of that person.
main_text.mn51:6.11: Well, now, sir, I must go.
main_text.mn51:6.12: I have many duties, and much to do.”
main_text.mn51:6.14: And then Pessa the elephant driver’s son approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
main_text.mn51:6.2: “Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.
main_text.mn51:6.3: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
main_text.mn51:6.4: The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
main_text.mn51:6.5: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
main_text.mn51:6.6: The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
main_text.mn51:6.7: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
main_text.mn51:6.8: The person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, extinguished, cooled, experiencing bliss, having become holy in themselves—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.
main_text.mn51:7.1: Then, not long after he had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
main_text.mn51:7.2: “Mendicants, Pessa the elephant driver’s son is astute.
main_text.mn51:7.4: If he had sat here a little longer so that I could have analyzed these four people in detail, he would have greatly benefited.
main_text.mn51:7.5: Still, even with this much he has already greatly benefited.”
main_text.mn51:7.6: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
main_text.mn51:7.7: May the Buddha analyze these four people in detail. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
main_text.mn51:7.8: “Well then, mendicants, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
main_text.mn51:8.1: “And what person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared for them, or an invitation for a meal.
main_text.mn51:8.10: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
main_text.mn51:8.11: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
main_text.mn51:8.12: They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening.
main_text.mn51:8.13: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
main_text.mn51:8.14: This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
main_text.mn51:8.2: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer.
main_text.mn51:8.3: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
main_text.mn51:8.4: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
main_text.mn51:8.5: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
main_text.mn51:8.6: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
main_text.mn51:8.7: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
main_text.mn51:8.8: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
main_text.mn51:9.1: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
main_text.mn51:9.2: It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, or poultry, a hunter or trapper, a fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher, a jailer, or someone with some other kind of cruel livelihood.
main_text.mn51:9.3: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

name: With Kandaraka

blurb: Asked by a householder to teach a path to freedom, Venerable Ānanda explains no less than eleven meditative states that may serve as doors to the deathless.

main_text.mn52:0.2: The Man From the City of Aṭṭhaka
main_text.mn52:1.2: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.
main_text.mn52:1.3: Now at that time the householder Dasama from the city of Aṭṭhaka had arrived at Pāṭaliputta on some business.
main_text.mn52:12.1: Furthermore, householder, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
main_text.mn52:12.3: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of infinite space is produced by choices and intentions.’
main_text.mn52:12.4: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …
main_text.mn52:13.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …
main_text.mn52:14.1: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
main_text.mn52:14.3: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of nothingness is produced by choices and intentions.’
main_text.mn52:14.4: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’

main_text.mn60:37.3: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.

main_text.mn76:5.9: “Sandaka, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was unfinished?”
main_text.mn76:50.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
main_text.mn76:50.2: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
main_text.mn76:50.3: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is no return to any state of existence.’
main_text.mn76:50.4: A sensible person would, to the best of their ability lead the spiritual life under a teacher who achieves such a high distinction, and, once practicing it, they would complete the procedure of the skillful teaching.”
main_text.mn76:51.1: “But Master Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—could they still enjoy sensual pleasures?”
main_text.mn76:51.2: “Sandaka, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetters of rebirth, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in five respects.
main_text.mn76:51.3: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they did as a lay person.
main_text.mn76:51.4: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these five respects.”
main_text.mn76:52.1: “But Master Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected, would the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended be constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?”
main_text.mn76:52.13: “In the same way, when a mendicant is perfected, the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended is not constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.
main_text.mn76:52.15: Rather, they are aware of it only when they checked it.”
main_text.mn76:52.3: “Well then, Sandaka, I shall give you a simile.
main_text.mn76:52.4: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
main_text.mn76:52.5: Suppose there was a person whose hands and feet had been amputated.
main_text.mn76:52.6: Would they be aware that their hands and feet had been amputated constantly and continually, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?
main_text.mn76:52.7: Or would they be aware of it only when they checked it?”
main_text.mn76:52.9: “They wouldn’t be aware of it constantly,
main_text.mn76:53.1: “But Reverend Ānanda, how many emancipators are there in this teaching and training?”
main_text.mn76:53.2: “There are not just one hundred emancipators, Sandaka, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that in this teaching and training.”
main_text.mn76:53.4: Namely, that there’s no glorifying one’s own teaching and putting down the teaching of others. The Dhamma is taught in its own field, and so many emancipators are recognized.
main_text.mn76:53.5: But these Ājīvaka ascetics, those sons of dead sons, glorify themselves and put others down. And they only recognize three emancipators:
main_text.mn76:53.6: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and Makkhali Gosāla.”
main_text.mn76:54.1: Then the wanderer Sandaka addressed his own assembly,
main_text.mn76:54.2: “Go, good sirs. The spiritual life is lived under the ascetic Gotama.
main_text.mn76:54.3: It’s not easy for me to give up possessions, honor, or popularity now.”
main_text.mn76:54.4: And that’s how the wanderer Sandaka sent his own assembly to lead the spiritual life under the Buddha.
main_text.mn76:6.1: “Sandaka, these things have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha: four ways that negate the spiritual life, and four kinds of unreliable spiritual life. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t succeed in the procedure of the skillful teaching.”
main_text.mn76:6.2: “But Master Ānanda, what are the four ways that negate the spiritual life, and the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life?”
main_text.mn76:7.1: “Sandaka, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
main_text.mn76:7.10: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and they don’t exist after death.’
main_text.mn76:7.2: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no obligation to mother and father. No beings are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is well attained and practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
main_text.mn76:7.3: This person is made up of the four primary elements. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the main mass of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
main_text.mn76:7.4: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
main_text.mn76:7.5: Their footprints show the way to the cemetery.
main_text.mn76:7.7: Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
main_text.mn76:7.8: Giving is a doctrine for morons.
main_text.mn76:7.9: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
main_text.mn76:8.1: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
main_text.mn76:8.11: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
main_text.mn76:8.12: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that both of us are annihilated and destroyed when our body breaks up, and we don’t exist after death.
main_text.mn76:8.13: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, perfumes, and makeup, and accepting gold and money. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
main_text.mn76:8.14: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
main_text.mn76:8.2: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
main_text.mn76:9.1: This is the first way that negates the spiritual life.

main_text.mn77:25.1: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to develop the four absorptions.
main_text.mn77:25.2: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
main_text.mn77:25.3: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
main_text.mn77:25.4: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. main_text.mn77:25.5: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
main_text.mn77:26.1: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption. main_text.mn77:26.2: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
main_text.mn77:26.3: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and no rainfall to replenish it from time to time.
main_text.mn77:26.4: But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
main_text.mn77:26.5: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
main_text.mn77:27.1: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’

main_text.mn94:10.2: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal.
main_text.mn94:10.3: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer.
main_text.mn94:10.4: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
main_text.mn94:10.5: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
main_text.mn94:10.6: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
main_text.mn94:10.7: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
main_text.mn94:10.8: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
main_text.mn94:10.9: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
main_text.mn94:11.1: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
main_text.mn94:11.2: It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.
main_text.mn94:11.3: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
main_text.mn94:12.1: And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
main_text.mn94:12.2: It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
main_text.mn94:12.3: He has a new temple built to the east of the city. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the temple with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
main_text.mn94:12.4: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
main_text.mn94:12.5: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. main_text.mn94:12.7: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
main_text.mn94:12.8: His bondservants, employees, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
main_text.mn94:12.9: This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.

main_text.mn94:14.1: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
main_text.mn94:14.2: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras and Brahmās, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
main_text.mn94:14.3: He teaches Dhamma that’s good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
main_text.mn94:15.1: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in some clan.

main_text.mn94:15.8: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of compassion for all living beings.
main_text.mn94:16.1: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.

main_text.mn94:16.3: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and trustworthy, and don’t trick the world with their words.
main_text.mn94:16.4: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
main_text.mn94:16.5: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
main_text.mn94:16.6: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
main_text.mn94:16.7: They avoid injuring plants and seeds.
main_text.mn94:16.8: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
main_text.mn94:16.9: They avoid dancing, singing, music, and seeing shows.
main_text.mn94:17.1: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.

main_text.mn94:17.4: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.

main_text.mn94:21.1: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged with their body straight, and establish mindfulness right there.
main_text.mn94:21.2: Giving up desire for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of desire, cleansing the mind of desire.
main_text.mn94:21.3: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of compassion for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
main_text.mn94:21.4: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
main_text.mn94:21.5: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
main_text.mn94:21.6: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
main_text.mn94:22.1: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.

main_text.mn94:25.1: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
main_text.mn94:26.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.

This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. main_text.mn94:27.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
main_text.mn94:27.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They spoke ill of the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never spoke ill of the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
main_text.mn94:28.1: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.

main_text.mn94:29.1: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.

blurb: The reputed brahmin Caṅkī goes with a large group to visit the Buddha, despite the reservations of other brahmins. A precocious student challenges the Buddha, affirming the validity of the Vedic scriptures. The Buddha gives a detailed explanation of how true understanding gradually emerges through spiritual education.

main_text.mn100:14.11: “In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who don’t live withdrawn in body and mind from sensual pleasures. They haven’t internally given up or stilled desire, affection, infatuation, thirst, and passion for sensual pleasures. Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are incapable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
main_text.mn100:14.12: This was the first example that occurred to me.
main_text.mn100:14.2: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water.
main_text.mn100:14.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking
main_text.mn100:14.4: to light a fire and produce heat.
main_text.mn100:14.6: By drilling the stick against that green, sappy log lying in water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”
main_text.mn100:14.9: Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.

Regardless of whether or not they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion, they are capable of knowledge and vision, of supreme awakening.
main_text.mn100:16.11: This was the third example that occurred to me.

main_text.mn100:16.3: Then a person comes along with a drill-stick, thinking

main_text.mn100:16.6: By drilling the stick against that dried up, withered log on dry land far from water, could they light a fire and produce heat?”

main_text.mn100:17.2: ‘Why don’t I, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, squeeze, squash, and torture mind with mind.’
main_text.mn100:17.4: until sweat ran from my armpits.
main_text.mn100:17.5: It was like when a strong man grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and tortures them.
main_text.mn100:17.6: In the same way, with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of my mouth, I squeezed, squashed, and tortured mind with mind until sweat ran from my armpits.
main_text.mn100:17.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

main_text.mn100:18.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
main_text.mn100:18.4: But then winds came out my ears making a loud noise,
main_text.mn100:18.5: like the puffing of a blacksmith’s bellows.
main_text.mn100:18.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.

main_text.mn100:19.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
main_text.mn100:19.4: But then strong winds ground my head,
main_text.mn100:19.5: like a strong man was drilling into my head with a sharp point.
main_text.mn100:19.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
main_text.mn100:2.1: Now at that time a brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī was residing at Caṇḍalakappa. She was devoted to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
main_text.mn100:2.2: Once, she tripped and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
main_text.mn100:2.3: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
main_text.mn100:2.4: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
main_text.mn100:2.5: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”
main_text.mn100:20.2: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’
main_text.mn100:20.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
main_text.mn100:20.4: But then I got a severe headache,
main_text.mn100:20.5: like a strong man was tightening a tough leather strap around my head.
main_text.mn100:20.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
main_text.mn100:21.2: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’
main_text.mn100:21.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
main_text.mn100:21.4: But then strong winds carved up my belly,
main_text.mn100:21.5: like a deft butcher or their apprentice was slicing my belly open with a meat cleaver.
main_text.mn100:21.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
main_text.mn100:22.2: ‘Why don’t I keep practicing the breathless absorption?’
main_text.mn100:22.3: So I cut off my breathing through my mouth and nose.
main_text.mn100:22.4: But then there was an intense burning in my body,
main_text.mn100:22.5: like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
main_text.mn100:22.7: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
main_text.mn100:23.1: Then some deities saw me and said,
main_text.mn100:23.6: ‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’
main_text.mn100:24.10: So I dismissed those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’
main_text.mn100:24.2: ‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’
main_text.mn100:24.3: But deities came to me and said,
main_text.mn100:24.4: ‘Good sir, don’t practice totally cutting off food.
main_text.mn100:24.5: If you do, we’ll infuse divine nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’
main_text.mn100:24.8: ‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing divine nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’
main_text.mn100:25.10: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
main_text.mn100:25.11: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
main_text.mn100:25.12: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
main_text.mn100:25.13: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
main_text.mn100:25.2: ‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a cup of broth made from mung beans, lentils, chickpeas, or green gram.’
main_text.mn100:25.4: until my body became extremely emaciated.
main_text.mn100:25.5: Due to eating so little, my limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a corpse,
main_text.mn100:25.6: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
main_text.mn100:25.7: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
main_text.mn100:25.8: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
main_text.mn100:25.9: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
main_text.mn100:26.1: Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’
main_text.mn100:26.2: Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’
main_text.mn100:26.3: Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has tawny skin.’
main_text.mn100:26.4: That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.
main_text.mn100:27.2: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.
main_text.mn100:27.5: But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work.
main_text.mn100:27.6: Could there be another path to awakening?’
main_text.mn100:28.2: ‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of the rose-apple tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
main_text.mn100:28.3: Could that be the path to awakening?’
main_text.mn100:28.4: Stemming from that memory came the realization:
main_text.mn100:29.2: ‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’
main_text.mn100:29.4: ‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’
main_text.mn100:3.1: Now at that time the brahmin student Saṅgārava was residing in Caṇḍalakappa. He was young, newly tonsured; he was sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies, ritual, phonology and etymology, and the testament as fifth. He knew philology and grammar, and was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
main_text.mn100:3.4: “The brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī is a disgrace! Though brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas are found, she praises that shaveling, that fake ascetic.”
main_text.mn100:3.5: “But my little dear, you don’t understand the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.
main_text.mn100:3.6: If you did, you’d never think of abusing or insulting him.”
main_text.mn100:3.7: “Well then, ma’am, let me know when the Buddha arrives in Caṇḍalakappa.”
main_text.mn100:30.2: ‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so excessively emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’
main_text.mn100:30.4: So I ate some solid food.
main_text.mn100:30.5: Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking,
main_text.mn100:30.6: ‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’
main_text.mn100:30.7: But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying,
main_text.mn100:30.8: ‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’
main_text.mn100:31-33.1: After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption …
main_text.mn100:31-33.2: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption …
main_text.mn100:34.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
main_text.mn100:34.2: I recollected many past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
main_text.mn100:35.1: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
main_text.mn100:35.2: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
main_text.mn100:36-38.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
main_text.mn100:36-38.2: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds …
main_text.mn100:36-38.3: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
main_text.mn100:36-38.4: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
main_text.mn100:39.1: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
main_text.mn100:39.2: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
main_text.mn100:39.3: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
main_text.mn100:4.1: And then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the Kosalan lands, arrived at Caṇḍalakappa,
main_text.mn100:4.2: where he stayed in the mango grove of the Todeyya brahmins.
main_text.mn100:40.1: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
main_text.mn100:40.2: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
main_text.mn100:40.3: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is no return to any state of existence.’
main_text.mn100:41.1: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
main_text.mn100:41.2: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.”

main_text.mn100:43.1: When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha,
main_text.mn100:43.3: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with good eyes can see what’s there, Master Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
main_text.mn100:43.4: I go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
main_text.mn100:43.5: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
main_text.mn100:5.1: Dhanañjānī heard that he had arrived.
main_text.mn100:5.2: So she went to Saṅgārava and told him, adding,
main_text.mn100:5.4: “Please, my little dear, go at your convenience.”
main_text.mn100:5.5: “Yes, ma’am,” replied Saṅgārava. He went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
main_text.mn100:5.6: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
main_text.mn100:6.1: “Master Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in the present life.
main_text.mn100:6.2: Where do you stand regarding these?”
main_text.mn100:7.1: “I say there is a diversity among those who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in the present life.
main_text.mn100:7.2: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are oral transmitters.
main_text.mn100:7.3: Through oral transmission they claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
main_text.mn100:7.4: For example, the brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas.
main_text.mn100:7.5: There are some ascetics and brahmins who solely by mere faith claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
main_text.mn100:7.6: For example, those who rely on logic and inquiry.
main_text.mn100:7.7: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, having directly known for themselves the principle regarding teachings not learned before from another, claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
main_text.mn100:8.1: And here’s a way to understand that I am one of them.
main_text.mn100:9.1: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
main_text.mn100:9.10: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own teacher’s doctrine with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
main_text.mn100:9.12: So far as lip-recital and oral recitation were concerned, I spoke with knowledge and the authority of the elders. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
main_text.mn100:9.14: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
main_text.mn100:9.15: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’
main_text.mn100:9.2: ‘Living in a house is cramped and dirty, but the life of one gone forth is wide open.
main_text.mn100:9.3: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
main_text.mn100:9.4: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
main_text.mn100:9.5: Some time later, while still black-haired, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
main_text.mn100:9.6: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
main_text.mn100:9.7: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
